Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Stellar Populations in Nearby Dwarf Galaxies
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goals of this project are to understand the assembly of the Milky Way, the assembly of its halo, and the behavior of dark matter halos in dwarf galaxies. The observations target dwarf galaxies in the Local Group which have been discovered by the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS). These faint, low-density, spheroidal, systems have experience tidal interactions and their stellar populations are stirred up. Another target is the apparently less disturbed, irregular Wolf-Lundmark-Melotte (WLM) galaxy that is more remote from the Milky Way's dark matter halo. The observations may help to distinguish between primordial objects made in dark matter halos, and objects formed in tidal interactions between galaxies.

A large number of stars in the fields of these newly discovered dwarfs ystems has already been observed with the Apache Point Observatory (APO) 3.5m and the CTIO 4-m telescopes. Here the Washington and Stromgren photometry of stellar populations is completed and analyzed to obtain stellar metallicities and ages. Additional low-resolution spectroscopy is used to further probe metallicities, and check on the memberships of the observed stars. In turn, this information constrains the initial mass functions and star formation histories of these faint dwarf systems.

This project supports research at an undergraduate institution and will introduce several undergraduate students to scientific research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported an ongoing observational program (awarded telescope time 2007-2014) to observe nearby dwarf galaxies surrounding the Milky Way. Dwarf galaxies can be thought of as the building blocks of larger systems like the Milky Way. Any understanding of the origins of our galaxy (and thus, the Earth) has to begin with its formation over twelve billion years ago, which is partly a cosmological question involving the nature and role of dark matter in the accretion and collapse of proto-galaxies. 

We imaged the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS)-discovered dwarf galaxies using the Washington CT1T2-filters (actually using CRI to reduce observing time), SDSS-u and g, and the Strömgren vby-filters (which are more sensitive to chemical composition, but are narrower filters). Of our target systems, we have completed the data analysis on the central field of Boötes I, and we have already collected most of the required data on four other dwarf spheroidal galaxies, and the more distant WLM dwarf irregular galaxy (which resides outside the Milky Way's dark matter halo). We have published most of the data on Boötes I in several papers, testing our photometric-metallicity calibration on a system with some recent spectroscopic measurements and our own theoretical models. We found that the lower red giant branch stars' colors, below the horizontal branch, were sensitive to chemical compostion and not age. This characteristic enabled us to show that there was an inhomogeneous spread in iron-content where the stars were too faint for high-reolution spectroscopy.
